{{short description|Global distribution of mangroves}} {{term paper|date=September 2012}}
'''Global [[mangrove]] distributions''' have fluctuated throughout human and [[Geology|geological]] history. The area covered by mangroves is influenced by a complex interaction between land position, [[rain]]fall [[hydrology]], [[sea level]], [[sedimentation]], [[subsidence]], storms and pest-predator relationships<ref name="Eslami-Andargoli et al. 2009">Eslami-Andargoli, L., Dale, P. et al. (2009). "Mangrove expansion and rainfall patterns in Moreton Bay, Southeast Queensland, Australia." [[Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science]] 85(2): 292–298.</ref><ref>"McLeod and Salm 2006" McLeod, E. and R. V. Salm (2006). Managing mangroves for resilience to climate change. Gland, Switzerland, The World Conservation Union (IUCN) 2.</ref>). In the last 50 years, human activities have strongly affected mangrove distributions, resulting in declines or expansions of worldwide mangrove area. Mangroves provide several important ‘free services’ including [[coast]]al stabilization, [[juvenile fish]] habitats, and the filtration of sediment and nutrients<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001">Valiela, I., Bowen, J. L. & York, J. K. 2001. Mangrove forests: one of the world's threatened major tropical environments. BioScience, 51, 807–815.</ref><ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996">Dierberg, F. E. & Kiattisimkul, W. 1996. Issues, impacts, and implications of shrimp aquaculture in Thailand. Environmental Management, 20, 649-666.</ref><ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007">Morrisey, D., Beard, C., Morrison, M., Craggs, R. & Lowe, M. 2007. The New Zealand Mangrove: Review of the Current State Of Knowledge. Auckland Regional Council.</ref>). Mangrove loss has important implications for coastal [[Ecology|ecological]] systems and human communities dependent on healthy mangrove ecosystems. This [[English Wikipedia]] page presents an overview of global [[Mangrove|Mangrove Forest]] [[biome]] trends in [[:Category:Mangrove ecoregions|mangrove ecoregion]]s distribution, as well as the cause of such changes.
As of 2012, mangroves are found in 105 nations globally.<ref name=":0" /> Although distributed across 105 nations, the top 10 mangrove holding nations contain approximately 52% of the global mangrove stock with Indonesia alone containing between 26% and 29% of the entire global mangrove stock.<ref name=":0" /> The largest continuous area of mangrove forest is likely in-and-around the Sundarbans National Park in India and the Sundarbans Mangrove Forests in Bangladesh,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Global Mangrove Forests Distribution, v1: Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) {{!}} SEDAC|url=http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/lulc-global-mangrove-forests-distribution-2000|doi=10.7927/h4j67dw8}}</ref> which are both recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Sites.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/?search=sundarbans&searchSites=&search_by_country=&region=&search_yearinscribed=&themes=&criteria_restrication=&type=&media=&order=country&description=|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - World Heritage List|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref> Although existing almost exclusively in the tropics and near-tropics, warm ocean currents support mangrove forests as far north as Walsingham Nature Reserve (Idwal Hughes Nature Reserve) in Bermuda and as far south as Snake Island, Australia.<ref name=":0" />
== Top 20 Mangrove Holdings Nations in 2012.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart E.|last2=Casey|first2=Daniel|date=2016-06-01|title=Creation of a high spatio-temporal resolution global database of continuous mangrove forest cover for the 21st century (CGMFC-21)|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/geb.12449/abstract|journal=Global Ecology and Biogeography|language=en|volume=25|issue=6|pages=729–738|doi=10.1111/geb.12449|issn=1466-8238}}</ref> ==
{| class="wikitable" |Rank |Country Name |Treecover in Mangrove Forests |Treecover in Wider Mangrove Biome |- | | |'''km2''' |'''km2''' |- |1 |Indonesia |23,324.29 |44,038.77 |- |2 |Brazil |7,674.94 |17,685.60 |- |3 |Malaysia |4,725.84 |8,231.09 |- |4 |Papua New Guinea |4,172.29 |5,677.16 |- |5 |Australia |3,316.21 |3,251.24 |- |6 |Mexico |2,991.83 |6,203.92 |- |7 |Myanmar |2,557.45 |3,856.09 |- |8 |Nigeria |2,653.99 |6,919.28 |- |9 |Venezuela |2,403.83 |7,539.12 |- |10 |Philippines |2,064.24 |2,089.24 |- |11 |Thailand |1,886.33 |4,196.97 |- |12 |Bangladesh |1,772.98 |2,314.56 |- |13 |Colombia |1,671.86 |6,274.70 |- |14 |Cuba |1,633.46 |2,454.10 |- |15 |United States |1,568.60 |1,585.06 |- |16 |Panama |1,323.94 |2,708.21 |- |17 |Mozambique |1,223.67 |2,677.27 |- |18 |Cameroon |1,112.76 |1,332.16 |- |19 |Gabon |1,082.11 |3,882.95 |- |20 |Ecuador |935.74 |1,945.27 |}
==Mangrove declines==
=== Global trends ===
In the last five decades, worldwide mangrove area has fallen across all regions.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Alongi 2002">Alongi, D. M. 2002. Present state and future of the world's mangrove forests. Environmental Conservation, 29, 331–349.</ref><ref name="FAO">FAO 2007. The World's Mangroves 1980–2005. FAO Forestry Paper. Rome: Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) no.153</ref> Different data sources or survey methods make estimates more problematic, as many nations have high variations of mangrove change.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001" /><ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="FAO" /><ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004">Barbier, E. & Sathirathai, S. 2004. Shrimp farming and mangrove loss in Thailand, Cheltenham, Edward Elgar Publishing.</ref>
'''Percentage of original area lost per year''' * Asia: 1.52% * Africa: 1.25% * Australia: 1.99% * Americas: 3.62% * The World: 2.07%
(based on data from)<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/> ''(Annual loss rates calculated from the mean number of years between original area and present area for each region: 24, 25, 7, 11, and 17 years for Asia, Africa, Australia, the Americas, and the world, respectively.) ''
From 2000 to 2012, the global mangrove deforestation rate was between 0.16% and 0.39% annually but as high as 3.58% to 8.08% in Southeast Asia.<ref name=":0"/> The most recent and comprehensive global assessment of mangrove distribution was conducted by Hamilton and Casey (2016) and provides a high-resolution global database of mangrove loss at the 1 arc-second level at annual intervals from 2000 to 2012 with estimates for 2013 and 2014.<ref name=":0"/> In the 1980s and 1990s the greatest amount of loss occurred, while in the period of 2000 to 2005 the rate has fallen significantly across all regions.<ref name="FAO"/> Some projections estimate that worldwide mangrove area will decline by a further 25% by 2025, particularly in developing nations.<ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006">McLeod, E. & Salm, R. V. 2006. Managing mangroves for resilience to climate change. Gland, Switzerland: The World Conservation Union (IUCN)</ref> It is estimated that since 1970, 28% of mangrove lost has been directly displaced by commercial aquaculture.<ref name="Hamilton 585–601">{{Cite journal|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart|date=2013-04-01|title=Assessing the Role of Commercial Aquaculture in Displacing Mangrove Forest|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/umrsmas/bullmar/2013/00000089/00000002/art00013|journal=Bulletin of Marine Science|volume=89|issue=2|pages=585–601|doi=10.5343/bms.2012.1069}}</ref>
===Role of perception=== People’s [[perception]] of mangrove ecosystems has been instrumental in the loss of mangroves. Commonly, they have been undervalued and considered ‘wastelands’ with low [[productivity]] (,<ref name="FAO"/><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/><ref name="Krauss et al. 2008">Krauss, K. W., Lovelock, C. E., McKee, K. L., Lopez-Hoffman, L., Ewe, S. M. L. & Sousa, W. P. 2008. Environmental drivers in mangrove establishment and early development: A review. Aquatic Botany, 89, 105–127.</ref>). Concerns for the fate of mangroves have historically been restricted to [[Scientific community|scientific communities]], with little transfer of knowledge to [[Local community|local communities]] and governments.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/> Mangroves are a [[Common-pool resource|common pool resource]], creating difficulties in enforcing restrictions on exploitative activities.<ref name="Idrus 2009">Idrus, M. R. 2009. Hard habits to break : investigating coastal resource utilisations and management systems in Sulawesi, Indonesia : a thesis submitted in partial of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Environmental Science at the University of Canterbury.</ref> More recently, perceptions have shifted to a broader acknowledgment within communities and governments of the value of mangroves in coastal ecosystems and local communities. The declining rate of mangrove loss since 2000 across all regions is indicative of this, bringing forth an increasing number of [[Conservation biology|conservation]] projects and [[legislation]].<ref name="FAO"/>
===Causes of decline=== A variety of factors have led to the declining trends in mangrove distribution (refer to table fig of causes). These factors are predominantly [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] in origin, as mangrove destruction is positively [[Correlation and dependence|correlated]] to human population density.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /> Up to 35% of mangrove forests worldwide have been lost since 1980, reflecting the increased pressure from high population densities residing at the [[coast]].<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="FAO"/> Mangrove losses to climate change are considered a probable long term threat to future distribution.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/> Despite a wide variety of factors linked to mangrove loss (insert figure of causes), the main drivers of recent (i.e. after 1980) mangrove destruction are linked to four main activities: [[urban sprawl]], [[tourism]], [[agriculture]] and [[aquaculture]].<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997">Farnsworth, E. J. & Ellison, A. M. 1997. The global conservation status of mangroves. Ambio, 328–334.</ref> The causes of declines in mangrove areas vary between regions. In [[Asia]], the [[Caribbean]] and [[Latin America]], aquaculture and tourism development are the greatest threat.<ref name="FAO"/> In [[Oceania]], tourism development is the greatest threat while in [[Africa]], conversion of mangroves for agricultural and urban development is most apparent.<ref name="FAO"/>
'''Aquaculture''' – This activity is considered the greatest contributor to worldwide mangrove loss.<ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006" /><ref name="Hamilton 585–601"/> Since the 1980s, [[shrimp]] aquaculture dramatically increased, replacing mangroves with ponds and degrading surrounding areas with associated pollution.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001" /><ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /><ref name="FAO" /> Aquaculture has dramatically affected some regions. For example, 50-80% of mangroves were lost in Asia in the past decades.<ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997" /> Asia, the Caribbean and Latin America have been most affected by aquaculture<ref name="FAO" />
[[File:Lone house in Petite-Anse (1180932461).jpg|thumb|Urban expansion - Urban development on mangrove habitat in [[Cap-Haitien, Haiti]]]]
'''Urban expansion''' – As population density increases at the coast, areas of mangrove forest have been replaced to provide urban and [[Industry|industrial]] lands.<ref name="FAO"/>
'''Tourism''' – infrastructure supporting tourism often requires the reclamation of substantial tracts of mangrove forests.<ref name="FAO"/> In the Americas and Oceania, tourism is a major driver of mangrove loss. Where tourism is a main contributor to an [[economy]] (such as Pacific Island nations), construction of [[resort]]s and related [[infrastructure]]s have reduced mangrove area in past decades.<ref name="FAO"/>
'''Agriculture''' – Conversion of mangrove forests for agriculture has occurred across all regions historically, freeing up land for activities such as rice or [[salt]] production (.<ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/>
[[File:ShrimpFarming Honduras L7 1987-99.jpg|thumb| Shrimp farming development in Honduras. Lower image is before devopment in 1987, upeer image is following expansion of ponds in 1999]]
====Mangrove loss case study: shrimp aquaculture in South-east Asia==== In many South-east Asian nations, shrimp aquaculture has been instrumental in mangrove loss, particularly in the 1980s and 1990s.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /><ref name="FAO"/> Due to high economic returns, shrimp farming was promoted to improve economic conditions in many countries.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /><ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /> The social and economic benefits of shrimp farming are substantial.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /> Shrimp farms are located close to the coast to reduce costs by using [[Tide|tidal]] energy and short [[canal]] lengths to the coast.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /> Consequently, vast tracts of mangrove forest have been replaced by numerous ponds. Compounding mangrove losses is the short life span of individual ponds (5–10 years), imposing a [[shifting cultivation]] pattern to shrimp farming.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/>
After 1980, shrimp farming became far more [[intensive]], with high productivity (per unit area) ponds proliferating across the landscape.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /> Dramatic reductions in mangrove forests were reported with shrimp pond intensification. In [[Thailand]], mangrove forests literally halved between 1975–1993<ref name="Aksornkoae and Tokrishna 2004">Aksornkoae, S. & Tokrishna, R. 2004. Overview of shrimp farming and mangrove loss in Thailand. In: Barbier, E. & Sathirathai, S. (eds.) Shrimp farming and mangrove loss in Thailand. Cheltenham Edward Elgar Publishing.</ref> The impact of such losses has been linked to the disruption of [[Ecology|ecological]] and economic functioning of mangroves.<ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /> For example, loss of income for local Thai fishermen has been reported due to reduced catches from the degradation of [[Juvenile (organism)|juvenile]] fish habitat.<ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /><ref name="Aksornkoae and Tokrishna 2004" /> Some consider that the number of shrimp farms in South-east Asia peaked in the late 1990s, with the rate of mangrove loss declining accordingly.<ref name="Aksornkoae and Tokrishna 2004" /> This decline is in part due to increased [[Conservation biology|conservation]] and [[Restoration ecology|restoration]] projects, and improved [[management]] practices.
===Global climate change and mangrove loss=== Increases in temperature, CO2, precipitation, storms, and sea level are likely to threaten mangroves in the future.<ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/> Sea level rise is considered the greatest [[climate change]] related threat to mangrove regions.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/> The natural ability of mangroves to ‘keep up’ with rising [[sea level]] through [[peat]] or [[sediment]] accumulation could be exceeded, leading to mangrove die back.<ref name="Ellison 1993">Ellison, J. C. 1993. Mangrove retreat with rising sea-level, Bermuda. [[Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science]], 37, 75–87.</ref>[[Low island]] mangroves are most at risk, as demonstrated in [[Bermuda]], where sea level rise has exceeded peat accumulation rates periodically, resulting in landward die back of mangrove stands.<ref name="Ellison 1993" /> Climate change may reduce global mangrove area by 10-15%, but it is a long term, less significance threat to the current 1-2% annual loss from human activities.<ref name="Alongi 2002" />
==Mangrove expansions==
=== Global trends ===
Several nations have experienced an expansion of their mangrove area. These expansions include human activities promoting seaward or landward expansion from climatic or other local factors, as well as conservation and [[reforestation]] programmes.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Saintilan and Wilton 2001" /> Globally, this stability and expansion is far outweighed by the magnitude of mangrove loss from human activities.
===Seaward expansion and human activity=== Seaward mangrove expansion is considered a natural response to high inputs of sediment and nutrients from human activity in adjacent [[Catchment area (human geography)|catchments]];.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Harty 2009">Harty, C. 2009. Mangrove planning and management in New Zealand and South East Australia - A reflection on approaches. Ocean and Coastal Management, 52, 278–286.</ref><ref name="Lovelock et al 2007">Lovelock, C. E., Feller, I. C., Ellis, J., Schwarz, A. M., Hancock, N., Nichols, P. & Sorrell, B. 2007. Mangrove growth in New Zealand estuaries: The role of nutrient enrichment at sites with contrasting rates of sedimentation.</ref> Mangroves naturally encourage [[sediment]] deposition by slowing [[Ocean current|currents]] and attenuating [[Wind wave|waves]]. However, with high [[sediment]] inputs, the elevation of [[intertidal]] flats can rise above the [[low tide]] limit of the original mangrove forest, resulting in a seaward expansion of new mangrove [[habitat]].<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /> Once new mangroves establish, they too begin to trap more sediment, raising the tidal flat elevation and generating more mangrove habitat.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /> Seaward expansions are likely in regions with modified catchments (i.e. deforestation or urban development) with high topography where high sediments loads are delivered to mangroves at the coast.<ref name="Harty 2009" /> Extremely high rates of sediment input can exceed tolerance thresholds and induce mangrove die backs.<ref name="Krauss et al. 2008"/> Excess sedimentation is the primary control, but [[nutrients]] (i.e. from [[agricultural runoff]]) can enhance mangrove expansion, particularly when combined with high levels of [[sedimentation]].<ref name="Lovelock et al 2007" /> Seaward expansions highlight the interconnectivity of mangrove ecosystems to adjacent catchments and the need to consider catchment alteration when managing mangroves.
[[File:SEAWARD mangrove migration.jpg|thumb| Conceptual model of seaward mangrove migrations]]
====Case study: New Zealand mangroves==== In [[New Zealand]] (NZ), [[temperate]] mangroves (Avicennia marina) are common in [[estuaries]], harbours and [[tidal]] creeks north of 38° latitude.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /> Following [[European colonization]], mangrove area declined, but since the 1970s rapid, ongoing seaward expansion has occurred in many areas.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Lovelock et al 2007" /><ref name="Park 2004">Park, S. 2004. Aspects of Mangrove Distribution and Abundance in Tauranga Harbour. Whakatane: Environment Bay of Plenty, 2004/16.</ref> For example, in the last 50 years mangrove area has expanded 120% in Tuaranga Harbour.<ref name="Park 2004" /> Such expansion is strongly correlated with elevated rates of sediment deposition. [[Drainage basin|Catchment]] activities such as [[deforestation]] and more recently, [[urban development]] have been blamed for the expansion.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Lovelock et al 2007" /><ref name="Park 2004" /> Considerable debate over whether to protect or remove NZ mangroves exist. Proponents for protection cite the ecological and coastal protection values of mangrove stands, while removal advocates aim to restore recreational values and prevent encroachment into non-mangrove ecosystems.<ref name="Harty 2009" /> A shift in the management strategy of regional councils from protection to mangrove ‘management’ has occurred recently<ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="De Luca 2009">De Luca, S. 2009. Mangrove Management - Balancing Values. Coastal News, NZ no. 42.</ref> Removals may take place when human amenities or non-mangrove habitats are deemed threatened by mangrove encroachment.<ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="De Luca 2009" /> Some researchers caution comparisons being made between NZ and [[tropical]] mangroves, suggesting NZ mangroves are unique in their ecology and require a tailored [[management]] approach.<ref name="Harty 2009" />
===Landward expansion=== In contrast to seaward expansions in NZ, [[landward]] expansions are documented in a number of regions ([[Thailand]], Australia, and [[Hawaii]]).<ref name="Eslami-Andargoli et al. 2009" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Saintilan and Wilton 2001">Saintilan, N. & Wilton, K. 2001. Changes in the distribution of mangroves and saltmarshes in Jervis Bay, Australia. Wetlands Ecology and Management, 9, 409–420.</ref><ref name="Chimner et al. 2006">Chimner, R. A., Fry, B., Kaneshiro, M. Y. & Cormier, N. 2006. Current Extent and Historical Expansion of Introduced Mangroves on O'ahu, Hawai'i1. Pacific Science, 60, 377–383</ref> The cause of landward expansions is not always clear. In Eastern Australia expansions have replaced salt marshes with various suggestions for the cause of landward expansion (increased rainfall, changes in hydrology, to local subsidence).<ref name="Eslami-Andargoli et al. 2009" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Saintilan and Wilton 2001" /> Expansions in Hawaii are thought to be the result of invasions by [[Invasive species|exotic]] mangrove species.<ref name="Chimner et al. 2006" />
===Expansion through conservation and restoration=== More recently, awareness of the economic, social, and [[ecological]] values of mangroves have led to an increase in the number of initiatives to protect and restore mangrove areas.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="FAO"/> Broader recognition of the connection of mangroves to coastal food chains, [[coastal protection]] and [[socio-economic]] welfare has driven recent conservation.<ref name="FAO"/> For example, [[Bangladesh]] has undertaken extensive coastal afforesation (mass plantings) projects since 1966, leading to an increase in mangrove area in recent decades;<ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Saenger N. A. 1993">Saenger, N. A. 1993. Land from the sea: the mangrove afforestation program of Bangladesh. Ocean & Coastal Management, 20, 23–39</ref> 2005;.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /> Many nations with mangroves have signed on to the 1971 [[Ramsar Convention]] on wetlands in the last two decades, making a commitment to [[wetland]] preservation.<ref name="Ramsar 1971">Ramsar. 1971. Ramsar Convention on Wetlands [Online]. Available: http://www.ramsar.org/cda/en/ramsar-about-about-ramsar/main/ramsar/1-36%5E7687_4000_0__ [Accessed April 2010].</ref> However, the adoption of protective [[legislation]] is not evenly spread. For instance, community initiatives to protect mangroves are common in Africa but little legislation exists compared to other regions, such as Asia.<ref name="FAO"/>
==Challenges, limitations and future suggestions== Much attention has been given to mangroves by the [[scientific community]], as well as a largely universal acknowledgement among communities and governments of the ecological and economic values.<ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/> Despite this awareness, global mangrove area continues to decline through human activities. A lack of communication between [[biologists]], effected residents, and governments could partly account for this.<ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/> Calls have been made for greater [[collaboration]] between international researchers and residents of affected nations. Efforts to assess changes in worldwide mangrove distribution have been hindered by a lack of long term data, or limited to no data at all for some nations.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/> Without accurate data on distributions, an accurate forecast of mangrove loss or expansion becomes problematic. This in turn may hinder the progress of [[Conservation biology|conservation]] projects. Despite large volumes of [[scientific literature]] on [[mangroves]], many uncertainties still exist. These include how mangroves will respond to increases in greenhouse gases and sea level, [[sustainable]] yields for silviculture, the difference in ecological functioning between tropical and [[temperate]] species, and why within the same species we get seaward and landward expansions.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Alongi 2002" /> Obtaining this knowledge will help nations to better predict future mangrove behavior, and administer appropriate [[management]] policies.
==Summary== Mangrove loss has been a worldwide trend for the last 50 years due primarily to [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] activities that compete for land area. Expansions in mangrove area do occur, but have a limited ability to offset the extensive losses. Recently the rate of loss has been declining due to a greater awareness of mangrove values, with legislation and conservation projects becoming more commonplace. It can only be hoped that this declining rate of loss continues, allowing future generations to appreciate the many benefits of mangroves.
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Mangrove]] - ''Mangrove Forest biome'' * [[:Category:Mangrove ecoregions|Mangrove ecoregions]] * [[Ecological values of mangrove]] * [[Coastal biogeomorphology]] * [[Coastal erosion]] {{col-end}}
